010package imagingbook.common.color.quantize;
011
012import java.util.Arrays;
013import java.util.LinkedList;
014import java.util.List;
015
016import ij.IJ;
017import ij.ImagePlus;
018import ij.process.ByteProcessor;
019import ij.process.ColorProcessor;
020import ij.process.ImageProcessor;
021import imagingbook.common.color.RgbUtils;
022
023/**
024 * This class implements color quantization based on the octree method. It is a
025 * re-factored version of an implementation ({@code OctTreeOpImage.java}) used in Sun's JAI 
026 * (Java Advanced Imaging) framework, which &ndash; in turn &ndash; is based on a 
027 * C implementation ({@code quantize.c}) by John Cristy in 1992 as part of 
028 * <a href="http://www.imagemagick.org/">ImageMagick</a>.
029 * The associated source code can be found 
030 * <a href="https://github.com/ImageMagick/ImageMagick/blob/main/MagickCore/quantize.c">
031 * here</a>, the original license note is provided at the bottom of this source file.
032 * 
033 * This implementation is similar but not identical to the original octree quantization
034 * algorithm described in
035 * <blockquote>
036 * M. Gervautz and W. Purgathofer, "A simple method for color
037 * quantization: octree quantization", in A. Glassner (editor), Graphics Gems I, 
038 * pp. 287â€“293. Academic Press, New York (1990).
039 * </blockquote>
040 * This implementation uses a modified strategy for pruning the octree for better efficiency.
041 * 
042 * "Quick quantization" means that original colors are mapped to their color index by simply
043 * finding the containing octree node. Otherwise, the closest quantized color (in terms of 
044 * Euclidean distance) is searched for, which is naturally slower.
045 * 
046 * @author WB
047 * @version 2017/01/03
048 */
049public class OctreeQuantizer implements ColorQuantizer {
050
051//      private final static int MAX_RGB = 255;
052        private final static int MAX_NODES = 262144 - 1; // = 2^18 - 1, was 266817;
053        private final static int MAX_TREE_DEPTH = 8;    // check, 7 enough?
054
055        private final int maxColors;    // max. number of distinct colors after quantization
056        
057        @SuppressWarnings("unused")
058        private final int nColors;              // final number of colors
059        private final TreeNode root;    // root node of the tree
060        
061        private int depth;                              // current depth of the tree
062        private int nodeCnt = 0;                // counts the number of nodes in the tree
063        private int colorCnt = 0;               // counts the number of colors in the cube (used for temp. counting)
064
065        private boolean quickQuantization = false;
066
067        // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
068        
069        public OctreeQuantizer(ColorProcessor ip, int K) {
070                this((int[]) ip.getPixels(), K);
071        }
072        
073        public OctreeQuantizer(int[] pixels, int K) {
074                this.maxColors = K;
075                this.root = new TreeNode(null, 0);
076                this.depth = Math.min(Math.max(log2(maxColors) - 1, 2), MAX_TREE_DEPTH);// 2 <= depth <= maxTreeDepth
077                
078                int initColorCnt = addPixels(pixels);
079                
080                this.nColors = reduceTree(initColorCnt, pixels.length);
081        }
082        
083        public void setQuickQuantization(boolean quickQuantization) {
084                this.quickQuantization = quickQuantization;
085        }
086        
087        // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
088        
089        private int addPixels(int[] pixels) {
090                for (int p : pixels) {
091                        addPixel(p);
092                        if (nodeCnt > MAX_NODES) { // a hard limit on the number of nodes in the tree
093                                root.pruneTree();
094                                depth--;
095                        }       
096                }
097                return colorCnt;
098        }
099
100        // walk the tree to depth, increasing the 'npixels' count in each node
101        private void addPixel(int p) {
102                TreeNode node = root;
103                node.nPixels++;
104                int[] rgb = RgbUtils.intToRgb(p);
105                for (int level = 1; level <= depth; level++) {
106                        int id = node.getChildId(rgb);
107                        if (node.childs[id] == null) {
108                                node = new TreeNode(node, id);  // create a new node at next level
109                        } 
110                        else {  // step to next level
111                                node = node.childs[id];
112                        }
113                        node.nPixels++;
114                }
115
116                // at level 'depth': update color statistics of this node
117                node.nUnique++;
118                
119                node.totalRed += rgb[0];
120                node.totalGrn += rgb[1];
121                node.totalBlu += rgb[2];
122        }
123
124        /**
125         * reduceTree() repeatedly prunes the tree until the number of
126         * nodes with unique > 0 is less than or equal to the maximum
127         * number of colors allowed in the output image.
128         * When a node to be pruned has offspring, the pruning
129         * procedure invokes itself recursively in order to prune the
130         * tree from the leaves upward.  The statistics of the node
131         * being pruned are always added to the corresponding data in
132         * that node's parent.  This retains the pruned node's color
133         * characteristics for later averaging.
134         * 
135         * @param initColorCnt 
136         *              The initial number of colors (leaves) in the octree.
137         * @param nSamples 
138         *              The total number of color samples used for creating the tree.
139         * @return
140         */
141        private int reduceTree(int initColorCnt, int nSamples) {
142                int minPixelCnt = Math.max(1,  nSamples / (maxColors * 8));
143                colorCnt = initColorCnt;
144                while (colorCnt > maxColors) {
145                        colorCnt = 0;   // for recounting the number of colors (leaves)
146                        minPixelCnt = root.reduceSparseNodes(minPixelCnt, Integer.MAX_VALUE);
147                }
148                return colorCnt;
149        }
150
151        private float[][] makeColorMap() {
152                List<float[]> colList = new LinkedList<>();
153                colorCnt = 0;   // used to store the color index in each node
154                root.collectColors(colList);
155                return colList.toArray(new float[0][]);
156        }
157        
158        /**
159         * Lists the octree nodes to System.out (intended for debugging only).
160         */
161        public void listNodes() {
162                root.listNodes();
163        }
164
165        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
166        
167        /**
168         * Represents a node in the octree.
169         */
170        private class TreeNode {
171                final TreeNode parent;          // reference to the parent node (null for the root node)
172                final TreeNode[] childs;        // references to child nodes
173                final int id;                   // branch index of this node at the parent node (0,...,7)
174                final int level;                // level of this node within the tree (root has level 0)
175                
176                int nChilds = 0;        // number of child nodes
177                int nPixels = 0;        // number of pixels represented by this node and all child nodes
178                int nUnique = 0;        // number of pixels represented by this node but none of the children
179
180                final int midRed;       // RGB color midpoint (center of this node in color space)
181                final int midGrn;
182                final int midBlu;
183                
184                int totalRed = 0;       // sum of all pixel component values represented by this node
185                int totalGrn = 0;
186                int totalBlu = 0;
187                
188                int colorIdx = -1;      // the index of the associated color in the final color table
189
190                TreeNode(TreeNode parent, int id) {
191                        this.parent = parent;
192                        this.id = id;
193                        this.childs = new TreeNode[8];
194                        nodeCnt++;
195
196                        if (parent == null) {   // this is the root node
197                                this.level = 0;
198                                // set this node's midpoint
199                                int mid = (MAX_RGB + 1) / 2;
200                                midRed = mid;
201                                midGrn = mid;
202                                midBlu = mid;
203                        }
204                        else {
205                                this.level = parent.level + 1;
206                                // attach this node to its parent
207                                parent.nChilds++;
208                                parent.childs[id] = this;
209                                // set this node's midpoint
210                                //int bi = (1 << (MAX_TREE_DEPTH - level)) >> 1;
211                                int bi = 256 >> (level + 1);
212                                midRed = parent.midRed + ((id & 1) > 0 ? bi : -bi);
213                                midGrn = parent.midGrn + ((id & 2) > 0 ? bi : -bi);
214                                midBlu = parent.midBlu + ((id & 4) > 0 ? bi : -bi);
215                                if (level == depth) {   // this is a leaf node
216                                        colorCnt++;
217                                }
218                        }
219                }
220
221
222                /**
223                 * Prune all nodes at the lowest level (= depth) of the tree.
224                 */
225                void pruneTree() {
226                        if (nChilds != 0) {     
227                                // move recursively to the lowest level
228                                for (int i = 0; i < childs.length; i++) {
229                                        if (childs[i] != null) {
230                                                childs[i].pruneTree();
231                                        }
232                                }
233                        }
234                        // work on the actual node now
235                        if (level == depth) {   // we are at a node on the lowest level
236                                delete();                       // remove THIS node!
237                        }
238                }
239
240
241                /**
242                 * Removes any nodes that hold fewer than 'minPixelCount' pixels
243                 * and finds the minimum population of all remaining nodes. 
244                 * 
245                 * @param minPixelCount The minimum population required for surviving nodes.
246                 * @param newMinPixelCnt The minimum population found so far (during recursive tree walk).
247                 * @return
248                 */
249                int reduceSparseNodes(int minPixelCount, int newMinPixelCnt) {
250                        // visit all child nodes first
251                        if (nChilds > 0) {
252                                for (TreeNode ch : childs) {
253                                        if (ch != null) {
254                                                newMinPixelCnt = ch.reduceSparseNodes(minPixelCount, newMinPixelCnt);
255                                        }
256                                }
257                        }
258                        // work on the actual node now
259                        if (nPixels <= minPixelCount) {
260                                this.delete();
261                        } 
262                        else {
263                                if (nUnique > 0) {
264                                        colorCnt++;
265                                }
266                                newMinPixelCnt = Math.min(nPixels, newMinPixelCnt); // find smallest population
267                        }
268                        return newMinPixelCnt;
269                }
270                
271                /**
272                 * Remove this node, and push all pixel statistics to its parent.
273                 */
274                void delete() {
275                        parent.nChilds--;
276                        parent.nUnique += nUnique;
277                        parent.totalRed += totalRed;
278                        parent.totalGrn += totalGrn;
279                        parent.totalBlu += totalBlu;
280                        parent.childs[id] = null;       // unlink
281                        nodeCnt--;
282                }
283                
284                /**
285                 * Calculates the branch index [0,...,7] out of this node
286                 * for the specified color.
287                 * @param red
288                 * @param grn
289                 * @param blu
290                 * @return The branch index [0,...,7].
291                 */
292                int getChildId(int[] rgb) {
293                        int idx = 0;
294                        if (rgb[0] > this.midRed) idx = idx | 0X01;
295                        if (rgb[1] > this.midGrn) idx = idx | 0X02;
296                        if (rgb[2] > this.midBlu) idx = idx | 0X04;
297                        return idx;
298                }
299                
300//              int getChildId(int[] rgb) {
301//                      int idx = ((rgb[0] > this.midRed ? 1 : 0) << 0) 
302//                                      | ((rgb[1] > this.midGrn ? 1 : 0) << 1)
303//                                      | ((rgb[2] > this.midBlu ? 1 : 0) << 2);
304//                      return idx;
305//              }
306                
307                /**
308                 * Collects the color entries for the color map. Any node
309                 * with a non-zero number of unique colors creates a color map
310                 * entry. The representative color for the node is calculated
311                 * as the average color vector over all contributing pixels.
312                 * 
313                 * @param colList List of colors to add to.
314                 */
315                private void collectColors(List<float[]> colList) {
316                        // visit all children first
317                        if (nChilds > 0) {
318                                for (TreeNode ch : childs) {
319                                        if (ch != null) {
320                                                ch.collectColors(colList);
321                                        }
322                                }
323                        }               
324                        // process this node
325//                      System.out.println("collectColors " + this.id + " unique=" + this.nUnique);
326                        if (nUnique > 0) {                      
327                                float avgRed = (float) totalRed / nUnique;
328                                float avgGrn = (float) totalGrn / nUnique;
329                                float avgBlu = (float) totalBlu / nUnique;
330                                colList.add(new float[] {avgRed, avgGrn, avgBlu});
331                                this.colorIdx = colorCnt;       // store the color table index for this node
332                                colorCnt++;
333                        }
334                }
335
336                private void listNodes() {
337                        if (nChilds > 0) {      
338                                for (TreeNode ch : childs) {
339                                        if (ch != null) {
340                                                ch.listNodes();
341                                        }
342                                }
343                        }
344                        // bottom of recursion
345//                      System.out.format(makeBlanks(level) + "node level=%d unique=%d total=%d: %3d %3d %3d, \n", 
346//                                      level, nUnique, this.nPixels, 0xFF & midRed, 0xFF & midGrn, 0xFF & midBlu); 
347                }
348                
349                @SuppressWarnings("unused")
350                private String makeBlanks(int level) {
351                        char[] blanks = new char[3 * level];
352                        Arrays.fill(blanks, '-');
353                        return new String(blanks);
354                }
355        }
356        
357        // ------- methods required by abstract super class -----------------------
358        
359        @Override
360        public float[][] getColorMap() {
361                return makeColorMap();
362        }
363        
364        @Override
365        public int findColorIndex(int p, float[][] colormap) {
366                if (this.quickQuantization) {
367                        return getNodeIndex(p);
368                }
369                else {
370                        return ColorQuantizer.super.findColorIndex(p, colormap);
371                }
372        }
373
374        /**
375         * Finds the associated color table index for the supplied RGB color
376         * by traversing the octree. 
377         * @param p
378         * @return
379         */
380        private int getNodeIndex(int p) {
381                int[] rgb = RgbUtils.intToRgb(p);
382                TreeNode node = root;
383                while(true) {
384                        int id = node.getChildId(rgb);  // which of the child nodes?
385                        if (node.childs[id] == null) {  // there is no finer-grained child node, so current 'node' is the one
386                                break;
387                        }
388                        node = node.childs[id];
389                }
390                // 'node' is associated with color p
391                if (node.colorIdx < 0) {
392                        throw new RuntimeException("cannot assign color " + p);
393                }
394                return node.colorIdx;
395        }
396        
397        private int log2(int n){
398                if(n <= 0) throw new IllegalArgumentException();
399                return 31 - Integer.numberOfLeadingZeros(n);
400        }
401        
402        // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
403
404        public static void main(String[] args) {
405//              String path = "D:/svn-book/Book/img/ch-color-images/alps-01s.png";
406                String path = "D:/svn-book/Book/img/ch-color-images/desaturation-hsv/balls.jpg";
407//              String path = "D:/svn-book/Book/img/ch-color-images/single-color.png";
408//              String path = "D:/svn-book/Book/img/ch-color-images/two-colors.png";
409//              String path = "D:/svn-book/Book/img/ch-color-images/random-colors.png";
410//              String path = "D:/svn-book/Book/img/ch-color-images/ramp-fire.png";
411                
412                int K = 16; 
413                System.out.println("image = " + path);
414                System.out.println("K = " + K);
415
416                ImagePlus im = IJ.openImage(path);
417                if (im == null) {
418                        System.out.println("could not open: " + path);
419                        return;
420                }
421                
422                ImageProcessor ip = im.getProcessor();
423                ColorProcessor cp = ip.convertToColorProcessor();
424                
425                // MedianCutQuantizer quantizer = new MedianCutQuantizer(cp, K);
426
427                OctreeQuantizer quantizer = new OctreeQuantizer(cp, K);
428                quantizer.setQuickQuantization(false);
429                quantizer.listColorMap();
430                
431                System.out.println("quantizing image");
432                ByteProcessor qi = quantizer.quantize(cp);
433                System.out.println("showing image");
434                (new ImagePlus("quantized", qi)).show();
435                
436        }
437}
438
439/*
440%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
441%                                                                             %
442%                                                                             %
443%                                                                             %
444%           QQQ   U   U   AAA   N   N  TTTTT  IIIII   ZZZZZ  EEEEE            %
445%          Q   Q  U   U  A   A  NN  N    T      I        ZZ  E                %
446%          Q   Q  U   U  AAAAA  N N N    T      I      ZZZ   EEEEE            %
447%          Q  QQ  U   U  A   A  N  NN    T      I     ZZ     E                %
448%           QQQQ   UUU   A   A  N   N    T    IIIII   ZZZZZ  EEEEE            %
449%                                                                             %
450%                                                                             %
451%              Reduce the Number of Unique Colors in an Image                 %
452%                                                                             %
453%                                                                             %
454%                           Software Design                                   %
455%                             John Cristy                                     %
456%                              July 1992                                      %
457%                                                                             %
458%                                                                             %
459%  Copyright 1998 E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company                        %
460%                                                                             %
461%  Permission is hereby granted, free of charge, to any person obtaining a    %
462%  copy of this software and associated documentation files ("ImageMagick"),  %
463%  to deal in ImageMagick without restriction, including without limitation   %
464%  the rights to use, copy, modify, merge, publish, distribute, sublicense,   %
465%  and/or sell copies of ImageMagick, and to permit persons to whom the       %
466%  ImageMagick is furnished to do so, subject to the following conditions:    %
467%                                                                             %
468%  The above copyright notice and this permission notice shall be included in %
469%  all copies or substantial portions of ImageMagick.                         %
470%                                                                             %
471%  The software is provided "as is", without warranty of any kind, express or %
472%  implied, including but not limited to the warranties of merchantability,   %
473%  fitness for a particular purpose and noninfringement.  In no event shall   %
474%  E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company be liable for any claim, damages or   %
475%  other liability, whether in an action of contract, tort or otherwise,      %
476%  arising from, out of or in connection with ImageMagick or the use or other %
477%  dealings in ImageMagick.                                                   %
478%                                                                             %
479%  Except as contained in this notice, the name of the E. I. du Pont de       %
480%  Nemours and Company shall not be used in advertising or otherwise to       %
481%  promote the sale, use or other dealings in ImageMagick without prior       %
482%  written authorization from the E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company.       %
483%                                                                             %
484%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
485%
486%  Realism in computer graphics typically requires using 24 bits/pixel to
487%  generate an image. Yet many graphic display devices do not contain
488%  the amount of memory necessary to match the spatial and color
489%  resolution of the human eye. The QUANTIZE program takes a 24 bit
490%  image and reduces the number of colors so it can be displayed on
491%  raster device with less bits per pixel. In most instances, the
492%  quantized image closely resembles the original reference image.
493%
494%  A reduction of colors in an image is also desirable for image
495%  transmission and real-time animation.
496%
497%  Function Quantize takes a standard RGB or monochrome images and quantizes
498%  them down to some fixed number of colors.
499%
500%  For purposes of color allocation, an image is a set of n pixels, where
501%  each pixel is a point in RGB space. RGB space is a 3-dimensional
502%  vector space, and each pixel, pi, is defined by an ordered triple of
503%  red, green, and blue coordinates, (ri, gi, bi).
504%
505%  Each primary color component (red, green, or blue) represents an
506%  intensity which varies linearly from 0 to a maximum value, cmax, which
507%  corresponds to full saturation of that color. Color allocation is
508%  defined over a domain consisting of the cube in RGB space with
509%  opposite vertices at (0,0,0) and (cmax,cmax,cmax). QUANTIZE requires
510%  cmax = 255.
511%
512%  The algorithm maps this domain onto a tree in which each node
513%  represents a cube within that domain. In the following discussion
514%  these cubes are defined by the coordinate of two opposite vertices:
515%  The vertex nearest the origin in RGB space and the vertex farthest
516%  from the origin.
517%
518%  The tree's root node represents the the entire domain, (0,0,0) through
519%  (cmax,cmax,cmax). Each lower level in the tree is generated by
520%  subdividing one node's cube into eight smaller cubes of equal size.
521%  This corresponds to bisecting the parent cube with planes passing
522%  through the midpoints of each edge.
523%
524%  The basic algorithm operates in three phases: Classification,
525%  Reduction, and Assignment. Classification builds a color
526%  description tree for the image. Reduction collapses the tree until
527%  the number it represents, at most, the number of colors desired in the
528%  output image. Assignment defines the output image's color map and
529%  sets each pixel's color by reclassification in the reduced tree.
530%  Our goal is to minimize the numerical discrepancies between the original
531%  colors and quantized colors (quantization error).
532%
533%  Classification begins by initializing a color description tree of
534%  sufficient depth to represent each possible input color in a leaf.
535%  However, it is impractical to generate a fully-formed color
536%  description tree in the classification phase for realistic values of
537%  cmax. If colors components in the input image are quantized to k-bit
538%  precision, so that cmax= 2k-1, the tree would need k levels below the
539%  root node to allow representing each possible input color in a leaf.
540%  This becomes prohibitive because the tree's total number of nodes is
541%  1 + sum(i=1,k,8k).
542%
543%  A complete tree would require 19,173,961 nodes for k = 8, cmax = 255.
544%  Therefore, to avoid building a fully populated tree, QUANTIZE: (1)
545%  Initializes data structures for nodes only as they are needed;  (2)
546%  Chooses a maximum depth for the tree as a function of the desired
547%  number of colors in the output image (currently log2(colormap size)).
548%
549%  For each pixel in the input image, classification scans downward from
550%  the root of the color description tree. At each level of the tree it
551%  identifies the single node which represents a cube in RGB space
552%  containing the pixel's color. It updates the following data for each
553%  such node:
554%
555%    n1: Number of pixels whose color is contained in the RGB cube
556%    which this node represents;
557%
558%    n2: Number of pixels whose color is not represented in a node at
559%    lower depth in the tree;  initially,  n2 = 0 for all nodes except
560%    leaves of the tree.
561%
562%    Sr, Sg, Sb: Sums of the red, green, and blue component values for
563%    all pixels not classified at a lower depth. The combination of
564%    these sums and n2  will ultimately characterize the mean color of a
565%    set of pixels represented by this node.
566%
567%    E: The distance squared in RGB space between each pixel contained
568%    within a node and the nodes' center. This represents the quantization
569%    error for a node.
570%
571%  Reduction repeatedly prunes the tree until the number of nodes with
572%  n2 > 0 is less than or equal to the maximum number of colors allowed
573%  in the output image. On any given iteration over the tree, it selects
574%  those nodes whose E count is minimal for pruning and merges their
575%  color statistics upward. It uses a pruning threshold, Ep, to govern
576%  node selection as follows:
577%
578%    Ep = 0
579%    while number of nodes with (n2 > 0) > required maximum number of colors
580%      prune all nodes such that E <= Ep
581%      Set Ep to minimum E in remaining nodes
582%
583%  This has the effect of minimizing any quantization error when merging
584%  two nodes together.
585%
586%  When a node to be pruned has offspring, the pruning procedure invokes
587%  itself recursively in order to prune the tree from the leaves upward.
588%  n2,  Sr, Sg,  and  Sb in a node being pruned are always added to the
589%  corresponding data in that node's parent. This retains the pruned
590%  node's color characteristics for later averaging.
591%
592%  For each node, n2 pixels exist for which that node represents the
593%  smallest volume in RGB space containing those pixel's colors. When n2
594%  > 0 the node will uniquely define a color in the output image. At the
595%  beginning of reduction,  n2 = 0  for all nodes except a the leaves of
596%  the tree which represent colors present in the input image.
597%
598%  The other pixel count, n1, indicates the total number of colors
599%  within the cubic volume which the node represents. This includes n1 -
600%  n2  pixels whose colors should be defined by nodes at a lower level in
601%  the tree.
602%
603%  Assignment generates the output image from the pruned tree. The
604%  output image consists of two parts: (1)  A color map, which is an
605%  array of color descriptions (RGB triples) for each color present in
606%  the output image;  (2)  A pixel array, which represents each pixel as
607%  an index into the color map array.
608%
609%  First, the assignment phase makes one pass over the pruned color
610%  description tree to establish the image's color map. For each node
611%  with n2  > 0, it divides Sr, Sg, and Sb by n2 . This produces the
612%  mean color of all pixels that classify no lower than this node. Each
613%  of these colors becomes an entry in the color map.
614%
615%  Finally,  the assignment phase reclassifies each pixel in the pruned
616%  tree to identify the deepest node containing the pixel's color. The
617%  pixel's value in the pixel array becomes the index of this node's mean
618%  color in the color map.
619%
620%  With the permission of USC Information Sciences Institute, 4676 Admiralty
621%  Way, Marina del Rey, California  90292, this code was adapted from module
622%  ALCOLS written by Paul Raveling.
623%
624%  The names of ISI and USC are not used in advertising or publicity
625%  pertaining to distribution of the software without prior specific
626%  written permission from ISI.
627%
628*/
